paragraphs.text: There is no debate about torture.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: The Senate Intelligence Committee's scathing torture report not only described the brutality of the CIA's interrogation methods, but also demonstrated their ineffectiveness
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Led by ex-Vice President Dick Cheney, former Bush administration officials have rushed to the airwaves to defend the CIA
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "I would do it again in a minute," Cheney said on NBC's Meet the Press
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: claiming that Enhanced Interrogation Techniques (EITs) produced "actionable intelligence that kept us safe from attacks"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Cheney & Co may not win the debate
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they have succeeded in muddying the waters
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That is unfortunate
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: because, beneath their bombastic caricatures of the torture programme, there's more agreement than first appears among people who actually count
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Aside from former officials trying to save their reputations, it isn't one camp saying torture didn't "work" and one saying it did
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Rather
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it's one camp saying it didn't, and the other saying "we have no idea but did it anyway"
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: On several key points, the CIA is closer in substance to the Senate report than to its loudest defenders
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: 'Unprepared' for torture
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: The Senate report found that the CIA was "unprepared" to operate a detention and interrogation system
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The Agency's written response to the report says;"We fully agree"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: the CIA had "no cadre of trained and experienced interrogators, little experience handling and moving prisoners, and no core competency in prison management
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The Agency had too few analysts and linguists with the expertise required to support[a detention] programme"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: In other words
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: there is no dispute that the programme was started and run on the fly
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A critical finding of the Senate report was that torturing detainees did not yield otherwise unobtainable actionable intelligence
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: CIA director, John O Brennan, admitted that the agency "has not concluded that it was the use of EITs that allowed us to obtain useful information from detainees"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: So
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: while
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the CIA still maintains that it gained valuable intelligence from detainees
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: it is not saying the abusive methods produced it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Senate report also describes how the CIA sought out two psychiatrists, James Mitchell and Bruce Jessen, to construct the torture programme instead of actual experienced interrogators, on the assumption that long-established humane and lawful interrogation methods wouldn't work
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: In its response, the CIA acknowledged that it had to look beyond the agency to find experts on "non-standard means of interrogation"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: since
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it was not an area of expertise that CIA officers or the US government possessed
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The CIA called Mitchell and Jessen's background "so unique" that the agency "would have been derelict had[it] not sought them out when it became clear that CIA would be heading into the uncharted territory of the programme"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: In other words
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the torture programme was so out of whack with what professional interrogators do that the CIA had to go outside the US government to find people to do it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: There still are important areas of disagreement between the Senate report and the CIA
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The CIA is too protective of its own to acknowledge the full import of its descent into torture or to disavow the programme entirely
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But the agency - unlike its loudest defenders - is not endorsing torture as a means of gaining intelligence or keeping the country safe
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: To be sure
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: basing the case against torture on its total ineffectiveness is a risky proposition
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Torture produces a lot of information
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: while
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: victims frequently make things up to ease their suffering
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: they may also on occasion say things of some value
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That's why it is important to remember that torture is illegal under any circumstances regardless of its utility
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But in a democracy, the strength of legal norms depends partly on their acceptance by the public
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: while
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the public shouldn't have to be persuaded that barbaric methods fail to make them safer
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: doing so reinforces their illegality
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The flurry of media appearances by Cheney and other torture defenders has created a false sense that there is a genuine divide over whether torture"works"
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But neither the CIA nor professional interrogators actually say that
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: while
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: we can continue to debate other aspects of the CIA programme
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: including whether those responsible should be sanctioned
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: let's stop pretending that there are two legitimate sides to this particular story
paragraphs.label: assumption
